conclusion: We are tasked with finding the magnitude of the external force F applied to slider B, given that both sliders are on the verge of not sliding upwards on the inclined plane.
Two sliders A and B are connected by a rope and placed on an inclined plane with an angle of 37 degrees. A horizontal force F is applied to slider B to the right.

The coefficient of kinetic friction between the sliders and the inclined plane is 0.5, and the maximum static friction is equal to the kinetic friction. It is known that sin 37 degrees = 0.6, and the gravitational acceleration is g.
Forces acting on slider A are gravitational force mg, normal force NA, frictional force fA, and tension T.

premise: Slider A is stationary, so net force along the incline is zero.
Substitute fA = mu NA and NA = mg cos theta.
conclusion: T = mg sin theta + mu (mg cos theta)
T = mg (sin theta + mu cos theta)
Forces acting on slider B are gravitational force mg, normal force NB, frictional force fB, tension T, and external force F.

premise: Net force along the incline for slider B is zero.
conclusion: F_parallel - T - mg sin theta - fB = 0

premise: F_parallel is the component of F along the incline.
Substitute fB = mu NB and NB = mg cos theta.
conclusion: F cos theta - T - mg sin theta - mu (mg cos theta) = 0
F cos theta = T + mg sin theta + mu (mg cos theta)

premise: Substitute T from slider A into slider B's equation.
conclusion: F cos theta = mg (sin theta + mu cos theta) + mg sin theta + mu (mg cos theta)
F cos theta = mg (2 sin theta + 2 mu cos theta)

premise: Divide both sides by cos theta.
conclusion: F = mg (2 sin theta + 2 mu cos theta) / cos theta

premise: Substitute known values: theta = 37 degrees, sin 37 degrees = 0.6, cos 37 degrees = 0.8, mu = 0.5.
